query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 E già la vita di quel lume santo 8 rivolta s’era al Sol che la rïempie 9 come quel ben ch’a ogne cosa è tanto.
query.result:
**English:**
7 And already the life of that holy light 8 had turned to the Sun which fills it, 9 like that good which is so much to every thing.
**Old English:**
7 And ða wæs ðæs halgan leohtes lif 8 onwended to ðære Sunnan ðe hit onfyllo, 9 swa ðæt god ðe is æghwylcum ðing swa micel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Ahi anime ingannate e fatture empie, 11 che da sì fatto ben torcete i cuori, 12 drizzando in vanità le vostre tempie!
13 Ed ecco un altro di quelli splendori 14 ver’ me si fece, e ’l suo voler piacermi 15 significava nel chiarir di fori.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Ah, deluded souls and wicked creatures, 11 who turn your hearts from such good, 12 directing your temples in vain!
13 And behold, another of those splendors 14 approached me, and his desire to please me 15 was signified in the brightness of his face.
**Old English:**
10 Eala, gedwolene sawla and yfele dada, 11 ðe fram ðam godan swa awendeð ða heortan, 12 and on idelnesse eowre getimbro fixiað!
13 And ða geseah ic ðær ðara leoma sumne 14 ongean me cuman, and his willan me to gecweman 15 on his ansyne bryhtmum me geswutelode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Li occhi di Bëatrice, ch’eran fermi 17 sovra me, come pria, di caro assenso 18 al mio disio certificato fermi.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Beatrice's eyes, which were fixed 17 upon me, as before, with dear consent 18 to my desire gave certain confirmation.
**Old English:**
16 Bēatricean ēagan, ðā wǣron fæste 17 ofer mē, swā ǣr, mid dēore andsware 18 mīnum gewilnunge getrymnesse fæste.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 «Deh, metti al mio voler tosto compenso, 20 beato spirto», dissi, «e fammi prova 21 ch’i’ possa in te refletter quel ch’io penso!».
query.result:
**English:**
19 "Ah, quickly grant my wish, 20 blessed spirit," I said, "and show me 21 that I can reflect in you what I think!"
**Old English:**
19 "Ea, syle me ðone willan ðinne hraðe, 20 ðu halga gast," ic cwæð, "and gefremma ðæt 21 ðæt ic on ðe mæge ðone geþoht oncirran!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Onde la luce che m’era ancor nova, 23 del suo profondo, ond’ ella pria cantava, 24 seguette come a cui di ben far giova:
25 «In quella parte de la terra prava 26 italica che siede tra Rïalto 27 e le fontane di Brenta e di Piava,
28 si leva un colle, e non surge molt’ alto, 29 là onde scese già una facella 30 che fece a la contrada un grande assalto.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Whence the light that was still new to me, 23 from its depths, where it first sang, 24 followed me, as one who is glad to do good:
25 "In that part of the wicked land of Italy 26 that sits between Rialto 27 and the springs of the Brenta and the Piave,
28 a hill rises, and it does not rise very high, 29 from which a torch once descended 30 that made a great assault on the countryside.
**Old English:**
22 Þanon ðæt leoht ðe mæ wæs ða gyt niwe, 23 of ðam deopan ðær hit ær song, 24 folgode me, swa ðam ðe wel dón lyste:
25 "On ðam dæle ðære wyrrestan eorðan 26 Itealie ðe stent betwux Ríalto 27 and ðara wælla of Brenta and of Piava,
28 arísð án beorg, and ne ástigeð swíðe heah, 29 ðanon ær gestah án fyrs, 30 ðe ðære contréan dyde mycelne andan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Di questa luculenta e cara gioia 38 del nostro cielo che più m’è propinqua, 39 grande fama rimase; e pria che moia,
40 questo centesimo anno ancor s’incinqua: 41 vedi se far si dee l’omo eccellente, 42 sì ch’altra vita la prima relinqua.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Of this resplendent and dear joy 38 of our heaven, which is closest to me, 39 great fame remained; and before I die,
40 this hundredth year is still added: 41 see if a man should make himself excellent, 42 so that the first life leaves behind another.
**Old English:**
37 ðyssere beorhtan and ðære leofan blisse 38 ðæs ure heofones ðe me is niehst, 39 mære mærðe wæs; and ær ðam ðe ic sceolde,
40 ðeos hundteontigoð git geðungen: 41 geseoh ðu ðæt ðe man sceal fremman, 42 ðæt ðæt oder lif ðæt æreste læte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Piangerà Feltro ancora la difalta 53 de l’empio suo pastor, che sarà sconcia 54 sì, che per simil non s’entrò in malta.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Feltro will weep again for the lack 53 of its wicked shepherd, who will be so disgraceful 54 that the like has never entered a ditch.
**Old English:**
52 Wepeð Feltria ðære forlorenan 53 hyre wyrrestan hyrdes, ðe ðær swa sconde 54 ðæt nan swylc ne com on dic.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Troppo sarebbe larga la bigoncia 56 che ricevesse il sangue ferrarese, 57 e stanco chi ’l pesasse a oncia a oncia,
58 che donerà questo prete cortese 59 per mostrarsi di parte; e cotai doni 60 conformi fieno al viver del paese.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Too large would be the vat 56 that could hold the blood of Ferrara, 57 and he who weighed it ounce by ounce would tire,
58 which this courteous priest will give 59 to show himself a partisan; and such gifts 60 will be in keeping with the life of the region.
**Old English:**
55 To micel wære ðæt fætels 56 ðe ðæt blod of Ferrarie onfenge, 57 and forworen se ðe hit wegan uncaunce,
58 ðe ðeos curteis preost gefan wille 59 for to scheawienne ðæt he is of ðære healfe; and swylce gifa 60 beoð gelice ðæs landes lare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Sù sono specchi, voi dicete Troni, 62 onde refulge a noi Dio giudicante; 63 sì che questi parlar ne paion buoni».
query.result:
**English:**
61 They are Mirrors, you say, Thrones, 62 from which God judging shines on us; 63 so that these words seem good to us.
**Old English:**
61 Hi sint speglas, ge secgað tronum, 62 ðanon us to scineð God deman; 63 swa ðæt ðeos spræc ðincð us god.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Qui si tacette; e fecemi sembiante 65 che fosse ad altro volta, per la rota 66 in che si mise com’ era davante.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Here he fell silent; and he made it seem to me 65 that he had turned to something else, because of the wheel 66 in which he placed himself as he was before.
**Old English:**
64 Þær he ða geswac; and me ða ðuhte 65 ðæt he wære on oðer geþoht gewend, for ðære hweole 66 on ðære he hine sylfne sette swa he ær wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 L’altra letizia, che m’era già nota 68 per cara cosa, mi si fece in vista 69 qual fin balasso in che lo sol percuota.
query.result:
**English:**
67 The other joy, which was already known to me 68 as a dear thing, appeared to me 69 like a fine ruby in which the sun strikes.
**Old English:**
67 Seo oðer gefean, ðe me ær wæs cuð 68 for ðære leofan ðinge, me wearð on gesyhðe 69 swylce fæger gim ðær ðe sunne on scineð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Per letiziar là sù fulgor s’acquista, 71 sì come riso qui; ma giù s’abbuia 72 l’ombra di fuor, come la mente è trista.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Through happiness, splendor is acquired there, 71 just as laughter here; but down below, 72 the shadow outside darkens, just as the mind is sad.
**Old English:**
70 Þurh ða blisse ðær ðæt leoht bið geceapod, 71 swa swa hleahtor her; ac niðer sceaðað 72 ðære dimme gesceaft, swa ðæs modes caru.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 «Dio vede tutto, e tuo veder s’inluia», 74 diss’ io, «beato spirto, sì che nulla 75 voglia di sé a te puot’ esser fuia.
query.result:
**English:**
73 "God sees everything, and your sight penetrates it," 74 I said, "blessed spirit, so that no 75 desire of itself can be hidden from you.
**Old English:**
73 "God gesihð eall, and ðin gesiho ðurhsihoð," 74 cwæð ic, "eadig gast, swa ðæt nan 75 will na mæg ðe befleon of himsylfum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Dunque la voce tua, che ’l ciel trastulla 77 sempre col canto di quei fuochi pii 78 che di sei ali facen la coculla,
79 perché non satisface a’ miei disii? 80 Già non attendere’ io tua dimanda, 81 s’io m’intuassi, come tu t’inmii».
query.result:
**English:**
76 Therefore, your voice, which delights heaven 77 always with the song of those pious fires 78 that make a cowl with six wings,
79 why does it not satisfy my desires? 80 I would not await your question, 81 if I understood myself, as you understand me.
**Old English:**
76 Forðæm ðin stefn, ðe ðone heofon trymð, 77 symle mid ðæm songe ðæra leohta geornra, 78 ðe ðara sixa wædra facað ðone cucull,
79 hwi ne gefylð hit ða mine wilnunga? 80 Ne sceolde ic ðine spræce ne geanbidan, 81 gif ic me sylfne cuðe, swa ðu me canst».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 «La maggior valle in che l’acqua si spanda», 83 incominciaro allor le sue parole, 84 «fuor di quel mar che la terra inghirlanda,
85 tra ’ discordanti liti contra ’l sole 86 tanto sen va, che fa meridïano 87 là dove l’orizzonte pria far suole.
query.result:
**English:**
82 “The greatest valley into which water spreads,” 83 his words then began, 84 “out of that sea which garlands the earth,
85 between the conflicting shores against the sun 86 it goes so far that it makes a meridian 87 where the horizon is usually accustomed to rise.
**Old English:**
82 “Se mæsta dæl ðær wæter on spryngð,” 83 ða ongunnon his word cweðan, 84 “of ðam sæ ðe ða eorðan ymbclyppeð,
85 betwux ðam unfrið gesamnodum landum ongean ða sunnan 86 swa feor gæð, ðæt hit mægðelstowe wyrceð 87 ðær ðe se sigefæst gewuna wæs ær up to donne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Di quella valle fu’ io litorano 89 tra Ebro e Macra, che per cammin corto 90 parte lo Genovese dal Toscano.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Of that valley I was a native, 89 between Ebro and Macra, which by a short course 90 divides the Genoese from the Tuscan.
**Old English:**
88 Of ðære dene wæs ic geboren, 89 betwux Ebro and Macra, ðe ðurh sceortne weg 90 todæleð ðone Genoeiscan fram ðam Tusciscan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Ad un occaso quasi e ad un orto 92 Buggea siede e la terra ond’ io fui, 93 che fé del sangue suo già caldo il porto.
query.result:
**English:**
91 At a sunset and at a sunrise 92 Buggea sits and the land from which I came, 93 which made its harbor warm with its blood.
**Old English:**
91 Æt anum setlgonge and æt anum upgange 92 Buggea sitteð and ðæt land ðe ic of com, 93 ðe geworhte ðæs blodes wærmne his brycg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Non però qui si pente, ma si ride, 104 non de la colpa, ch’a mente non torna, 105 ma del valor ch’ordinò e provide.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Not, however, does one repent here, but one laughs, 104 not of the sin, which does not come to mind, 105 but of the valor that ordained and provided.
**Old English:**
103 Ne ðær mon hreowð, ac ðær mon hlihð, 104 ne ðære gylte, ðe on mod ne gæð, 105 ac ðæs wæðan, ðe geworhte and geworðode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Qui si rimira ne l’arte ch’addorna 107 cotanto affetto, e discernesi ’l bene 108 per che ’l mondo di sù quel di giù torna.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Here one can see again in the art that adorns 107 so much affection, and one discerns the good 108 for which the world above returns to the world below.
**Old English:**
106 Hēr mæg mon eft geseon on ðære gife ðe geglencð 107 swylce lufe, and ðæt god oncnāwð 108 for ðȳ ðe ðeos woruld ðone ufan eft gecyrð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Ma perché tutte le tue voglie piene 110 ten porti che son nate in questa spera, 111 proceder ancor oltre mi convene.
query.result:
**English:**
109 But because you fulfill all your desires 110 that are born in this sphere, 111 I must proceed even further.
**Old English:**
109 Ac forðæmðeðuðinewilleðinefyllest, 110 ðe onðissereearonacennede, 111 ðonnemosticðuðurhðisfurðorðon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Tu vuo’ saper chi è in questa lumera 113 che qui appresso me così scintilla 114 come raggio di sole in acqua mera.
query.result:
**English:**
112 You want to know who is in this light 113 that here beside me sparkles so 114 like a ray of sun in pure water.
**Old English:**
112 ðu woldest witan hwa is on ðisse leohte 113 ðe her be sidan me swa scinð 114 swa sunnan gleam on wætere steapum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Or sappi che là entro si tranquilla 116 Raab; e a nostr’ ordine congiunta, 117 di lei nel sommo grado si sigilla.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Now know that Rahab is tranquil there, 116 and joined to our order, 117 and in its highest grade she is sealed.
**Old English:**
115 Nu ðu scealt witan ðæt ðær binnan wunað 116 Rahab, and is ure sibbe, 117 and on ðæm heahstan hade is heo gehealden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Da questo cielo, in cui l’ombra s’appunta 119 che ’l vostro mondo face, pria ch’altr’ alma 120 del trïunfo di Cristo fu assunta.
query.result:
**English:**
118 From this heaven, where the shadow ends 119 that your world makes, before any other soul 120 was assumed into the triumph of Christ.
**Old English:**
118 Of ðissum heofone, ðær ðæs sceаdu scyneð 119 ðe eоwer weoruld wyrceð, ær ðonne ænig oðer sawl 120 wære to Criste on sigeферыd genumen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Ben si convenne lei lasciar per palma 122 in alcun cielo de l’alta vittoria 123 che s’acquistò con l’una e l’altra palma,
124 perch’ ella favorò la prima gloria 125 di Iosüè in su la Terra Santa, 126 che poco tocca al papa la memoria.
query.result:
**English:**
121 It was fitting that she should leave him for a palm 122 in some heaven of the high victory 123 that she acquired with one palm and the other,
124 because she favored the first glory 125 of Joshua in the Holy Land, 126 which the pope scarcely remembers.
**Old English:**
121 Wel gebyrede ðæt heo hine forlete for palman 122 on sumum heofone ðære hean oferwinnan, 123 ðe heo begeat mid ðære anan and ðære oðran palman,
124 forðæm heo fremode ða ærestan wuldor 125 Iosue on ðære Halgan Eorðan, 126 ðe ðæs papan gemynd lythwon hrepoð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 La tua città, che di colui è pianta 128 che pria volse le spalle al suo fattore 129 e di cui è la ’nvidia tanto pianta,
130 produce e spande il maladetto fiore 131 c’ha disvïate le pecore e li agni, 132 però che fatto ha lupo del pastore.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Your city, which is founded by him 128 who first turned his back on his Creator 129 and because of whom envy is so lamented,
130 produces and spreads the accursed flower 131 that has led astray the sheep and the lambs, 132 because it has made a wolf of the shepherd.
**Old English:**
127 Þin burg, ðe is getimbred fram ðæm 128 ðe ær his Scyppende bæc bitwænde 129 and ðæs is ðæt andan swa micel,
130 awyrð æppel awecð and awyrpð, 131 ðe ða sceap and ða lomb forlædde, 132 forðæm ðe he ðone hyrde to wulfe geworhte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Per questo l’Evangelio e i dottor magni 134 son derelitti, e solo ai Decretali 135 si studia, sì che pare a’ lor vivagni.
query.result:
**English:**
133 For this reason the Gospel and the great doctors 134 are abandoned, and only the Decretals 135 are studied, so that it seems to their disciples
**Old English:**
133 For ðære tide ðæt Godspell and ða mæran lareowas 134 sind forlætene, and ða Decretales ane 135 sind smealice, swa ðæt hyra leorningcnihtum ðinceð

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 A questo intende il papa e ’ cardinali; 137 non vanno i lor pensieri a Nazarette, 138 là dove Gabrïello aperse l’ali.
query.result:
**English:**
136 To this the pope and the cardinals direct their thoughts; 137 their thoughts do not go to Nazareth, 138 where Gabriel opened his wings.
**Old English:**
136 To ðisum ðæs papan and ðara bisceopa ðohtas synt gebundene; 137 ne beoð heora ðohtas on Nazareth, 138 ðær ðe Gabriel hys fyðru onbrygde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Ma Vaticano e l’altre parti elette 140 di Roma che son state cimitero 141 a la milizia che Pietro seguette,
142 tosto libere fien de l’avoltero».
query.result:
**English:**
139 But the Vatican and the other parts chosen 140 of Rome which have been a cemetery 141 for the soldiery that followed Peter,
142 will soon be free from the adulterer.
**Old English:**
139 Ac ðæt fæsten and ða oðre dæl 140 Rome ðe wæron ðara byrigene 141 ðæra þegnum ðe Petre folgodon,
142 beoð sona alysede fram ðam unrihtwisan.
